natural problem: The probability of getting rain on any given day in June in Capital City is $\frac{1}{10}$.  What is the probability that it rains on at most 2 days in June?  Express your answer as a decimal to the nearest thousandth.
natural solution: There are 30 days in June. The probability that it rains on exactly 0, 1, or 2 days is  \begin{align}&\ \ \ \ \binom{30}{0}\bigg(\frac{1}{10}\bigg)^{\!0}\bigg(\frac{9}{10}\bigg)^{\!30}\\&+\binom{30}{1}\bigg(\frac{1}{10}\bigg)^{\!1}\bigg(\frac{9}{10}\bigg)^{\!29}\\&+\binom{30}{2}\bigg(\frac{1}{10}\bigg)^{\!2}\bigg(\frac{9}{10}\bigg)^{\!28} \\

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes rain_probability :: real
and rain_at_most_2_days :: real
assumes h0 : "rain_probability = 1 / 10"
and h1 : "rain_at_most_2_days = (binomial 30 0) * (rain_probability ^ 0) * ((1 - rain_probability) ^ 30) +
                                (binomial 30 1) * (rain_probability ^ 1) * ((1 - rain_probability) ^ 29) +
                                (binomial 30 2) * (rain_probability ^ 2) * ((1 - rain_probability) ^ 28)"
shows  "rain_at_most_2_days \<approx> 0.411"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 The probability of getting rain on any given day in June in Capital City is $\frac{1}{10}$.  What is the probability that it rains on at most 2 days in June?  Express your answer as a decimal to the nearest thousandth. The final Answer is 0.411
 ### Proof
 There are 30 days in June. The probability that it rains on exactly 0, 1, or 2 days is  \begin{align}&\ \ \ \ \binom{30}{0}\bigg(\frac{1}{10}\bigg)^{\!0}\bigg(\frac{9}{10}\bigg)^{\!30}\\&+\binom{30}{1}\bigg(\frac{1}{10}\bigg)^{\!1}\bigg(\frac{9}{10}\bigg)^{\!29}\\&+\binom{30}{2}\bigg(\frac{1}{10}\bigg)^{\!2}\bigg(\frac{9}{10}\bigg)^{\!28} \\
 &\approx \boxed{0.411}.\end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes rain_probability :: real
and rain_at_most_2_days :: real
assumes h0 : "rain_probability = 1 / 10"
and h1 : "rain_at_most_2_days = (binomial 30 0) * (rain_probability ^ 0) * ((1 - rain_probability) ^ 30) +
                                (binomial 30 1) * (rain_probability ^ 1) * ((1 - rain_probability) ^ 29) +
                                (binomial 30 2) * (rain_probability ^ 2) * ((1 - rain_probability) ^ 28)"
shows  "rain_at_most_2_days \<approx> 0.411"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: In a 30-day month, the probability of rain on any given day is $\frac{1}{10}$. What is the probability that it will rain on at most 2 days during the month? The final answer is approximately $0.411$.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes p_rain :: real and P :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "p_rain = 1 / 10"
and h1 : "\<forall> n. P n = nchoosek 30 n * p_rain powr n * (1 - p_rain) powr (30 - n)"
shows  "P 0 + P 1 + P 2 \<approx> 0.411"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 The probability of getting rain on any given day in June in Capital City is $\frac{1}{10}$.  What is the probability that it rains on at most 2 days in June?  Express your answer as a decimal to the nearest thousandth. The final Answer is 0.411
 ### Proof
 There are 30 days in June. The probability that it rains on exactly 0, 1, or 2 days is  \begin{align}&\ \ \ \ \binom{30}{0}\bigg(\frac{1}{10}\bigg)^{\!0}\bigg(\frac{9}{10}\bigg)^{\!30}\\&+\binom{30}{1}\bigg(\frac{1}{10}\bigg)^{\!1}\bigg(\frac{9}{10}\bigg)^{\!29}\\&+\binom{30}{2}\bigg(\frac{1}{10}\bigg)^{\!2}\bigg(\frac{9}{10}\bigg)^{\!28} \\
 &\approx \boxed{0.411}.\end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes p_rain :: real and P :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "p_rain = 1 / 10"
and h1 : "\<forall> n. P n = nchoosek 30 n * p_rain powr n * (1 - p_rain) powr (30 - n)"
shows  "P 0 + P 1 + P 2 \<approx> 0.411"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: Suppose the probability of rain on a given day is $\frac{1}{10}$. What is the approximate probability that it will rain at most 2 days out of the next 30 days? The final answer is approximately $0.411$.

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes probability_rain :: real
and P_at_most_2_rain :: real
assumes h0 : "probability_rain = 1 / 10"
and h1 : "P_at_most_2_rain = (\<Sum>k = 0..2. (30 choose k) * (probability_rain^k) * ((1 - probability_rain)^(30 - k)))"
shows  "P_at_most_2_rain = (0.411 :: real)"
a_2.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 The probability of getting rain on any given day in June in Capital City is $\frac{1}{10}$.  What is the probability that it rains on at most 2 days in June?  Express your answer as a decimal to the nearest thousandth. The final Answer is 0.411
 ### Proof
 There are 30 days in June. The probability that it rains on exactly 0, 1, or 2 days is  \begin{align}&\ \ \ \ \binom{30}{0}\bigg(\frac{1}{10}\bigg)^{\!0}\bigg(\frac{9}{10}\bigg)^{\!30}\\&+\binom{30}{1}\bigg(\frac{1}{10}\bigg)^{\!1}\bigg(\frac{9}{10}\bigg)^{\!29}\\&+\binom{30}{2}\bigg(\frac{1}{10}\bigg)^{\!2}\bigg(\frac{9}{10}\bigg)^{\!28} \\
 &\approx \boxed{0.411}.\end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes probability_rain :: real
and P_at_most_2_rain :: real
assumes h0 : "probability_rain = 1 / 10"
and h1 : "P_at_most_2_rain = (\<Sum>k = 0..2. (30 choose k) * (probability_rain^k) * ((1 - probability_rain)^(30 - k)))"
shows  "P_at_most_2_rain = (0.411 :: real)"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_2.informal problem: In a month with 30 days, the probability that it will rain on any given day is 1/10. What is the probability that it rains on at most 2 days in the entire month? The final answer is 0.411.

a_3.formal problem:
theorem
fixes P :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "P 0 = 9/10 * 9/10 * 9/10"
and h1 : "P 1 = 9/10 * 9/10 * 1/10"
and h2 : "P 2 = 9/10 * 1/10 * 1/10"
and h3 : "P 3 = 1/10 * 1/10 * 1/10"
and h4 : "\<forall>k. 0 \<le> k \<and> k \<le> 2 \<longrightarrow> 0 \<le> P k \<and> P k \<le> 1"
shows  "sum P {0,1,2} = 0.411"
a_3.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 The probability of getting rain on any given day in June in Capital City is $\frac{1}{10}$.  What is the probability that it rains on at most 2 days in June?  Express your answer as a decimal to the nearest thousandth. The final Answer is 0.411
 ### Proof
 There are 30 days in June. The probability that it rains on exactly 0, 1, or 2 days is  \begin{align}&\ \ \ \ \binom{30}{0}\bigg(\frac{1}{10}\bigg)^{\!0}\bigg(\frac{9}{10}\bigg)^{\!30}\\&+\binom{30}{1}\bigg(\frac{1}{10}\bigg)^{\!1}\bigg(\frac{9}{10}\bigg)^{\!29}\\&+\binom{30}{2}\bigg(\frac{1}{10}\bigg)^{\!2}\bigg(\frac{9}{10}\bigg)^{\!28} \\
 &\approx \boxed{0.411}.\end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes P :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "P 0 = 9/10 * 9/10 * 9/10"
and h1 : "P 1 = 9/10 * 9/10 * 1/10"
and h2 : "P 2 = 9/10 * 1/10 * 1/10"
and h3 : "P 3 = 1/10 * 1/10 * 1/10"
and h4 : "\<forall>k. 0 \<le> k \<and> k \<le> 2 \<longrightarrow> 0 \<le> P k \<and> P k \<le> 1"
shows  "sum P {0,1,2} = 0.411"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_3.informal problem:
A box contains three balls numbered 0, 1, and 2. The probability of drawing a ball with the number $k$ is given by:

- $P(0) = \frac{9}{10} \cdot \frac{9}{10} \cdot \frac{9}{10}$
- $P(1) = \frac{9}{10} \cdot \frac{9}{10} \cdot \frac{1}{10}$
- $P(2) = \frac{9}{10} \cdot \frac{1}{10} \cdot \frac{1}{10}$
- $P(3) = \frac{1}{10} \cdot \frac{1}{10} \cdot \frac{1}{10}$

Find the sum of the probabilities of drawing balls numbered 0, 1, and 2. The final answer is 0.411.

a_4.formal problem:
theorem
fixes p_rain :: real and p_at_most_2 :: real
assumes h0 : "p_rain = 1/10"
and h1 : "p_at_most_2 = (\<Sum> i \<in> {0..2}. (30 choose i) * (p_rain ^ i) * ((1 - p_rain) ^ (30 - i)))"
shows  "p_at_most_2 = 0.411"
a_4.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 The probability of getting rain on any given day in June in Capital City is $\frac{1}{10}$.  What is the probability that it rains on at most 2 days in June?  Express your answer as a decimal to the nearest thousandth. The final Answer is 0.411
 ### Proof
 There are 30 days in June. The probability that it rains on exactly 0, 1, or 2 days is  \begin{align}&\ \ \ \ \binom{30}{0}\bigg(\frac{1}{10}\bigg)^{\!0}\bigg(\frac{9}{10}\bigg)^{\!30}\\&+\binom{30}{1}\bigg(\frac{1}{10}\bigg)^{\!1}\bigg(\frac{9}{10}\bigg)^{\!29}\\&+\binom{30}{2}\bigg(\frac{1}{10}\bigg)^{\!2}\bigg(\frac{9}{10}\bigg)^{\!28} \\
 &\approx \boxed{0.411}.\end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes p_rain :: real and p_at_most_2 :: real
assumes h0 : "p_rain = 1/10"
and h1 : "p_at_most_2 = (\<Sum> i \<in> {0..2}. (30 choose i) * (p_rain ^ i) * ((1 - p_rain) ^ (30 - i)))"
shows  "p_at_most_2 = 0.411"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_4.informal problem: A weather forecast says there is a 1/10 chance of rain each day for the next 30 days. What is the probability that it will rain on at most 2 of those days? The final answer is approximately 0.411.

a_5.formal problem:
theorem
fixes P_rain P_at_most_2_rainy_days :: real
assumes h0 : "P_rain = 1 / 10"
and h1 : "P_at_most_2_rainy_days = (\<Sum>k\<in>{0..2}. (30 choose k) * P_rain powr k * (1 - P_rain) powr (30 - k))"
shows  "P_at_most_2_rainy_days = 0.411"
a_5.formal solution:

 The probability of getting rain on any given day in June in Capital City is $\frac{1}{10}$.  What is the probability that it rains on at most 2 days in June?  Express your answer as a decimal to the nearest thousandth. The final Answer is 0.411
 ### Proof
 There are 30 days in June. The probability that it rains on exactly 0, 1, or 2 days is  \begin{align}&\ \ \ \ \binom{30}{0}\bigg(\frac{1}{10}\bigg)^{\!0}\bigg(\frac{9}{10}\bigg)^{\!30}\\&+\binom{30}{1}\bigg(\frac{1}{10}\bigg)^{\!1}\bigg(\frac{9}{10}\bigg)^{\!29}\\&+\binom{30}{2}\bigg(\frac{1}{10}\bigg)^{\!2}\bigg(\frac{9}{10}\bigg)^{\!28} \\

a_5.informal problem: In a month with 30 days, the probability of rain on any given day is 1/10. What is the probability that there are at most 2 rainy days in the month? The final answer is 0.411.

a_6.formal problem:
theorem
fixes prob_rain :: real
assumes h0 : "prob_rain = 1 / 10"
and h1 : "\<forall>n k. binomial_pmf n k prob_rain = (n choose k) * prob_rain powr k * (1 - prob_rain) powr (n - k)"
shows  "binomial_pmf 30 0 prob_rain + binomial_pmf 30 1 prob_rain + binomial_pmf 30 2 prob_rain \<approx> 0.411"
a_6.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 The probability of getting rain on any given day in June in Capital City is $\frac{1}{10}$.  What is the probability that it rains on at most 2 days in June?  Express your answer as a decimal to the nearest thousandth. The final Answer is 0.411
 ### Proof
 There are 30 days in June. The probability that it rains on exactly 0, 1, or 2 days is  \begin{align}&\ \ \ \ \binom{30}{0}\bigg(\frac{1}{10}\bigg)^{\!0}\bigg(\frac{9}{10}\bigg)^{\!30}\\&+\binom{30}{1}\bigg(\frac{1}{10}\bigg)^{\!1}\bigg(\frac{9}{10}\bigg)^{\!29}\\&+\binom{30}{2}\bigg(\frac{1}{10}\bigg)^{\!2}\bigg(\frac{9}{10}\bigg)^{\!28} \\
 &\approx \boxed{0.411}.\end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes prob_rain :: real
assumes h0 : "prob_rain = 1 / 10"
and h1 : "\<forall>n k. binomial_pmf n k prob_rain = (n choose k) * prob_rain powr k * (1 - prob_rain) powr (n - k)"
shows  "binomial_pmf 30 0 prob_rain + binomial_pmf 30 1 prob_rain + binomial_pmf 30 2 prob_rain \<approx> 0.411"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_6.informal problem: There is a 1/10 chance of rain on any given day. If you want to know the probability that it rains 0, 1, or 2 days out of a 30-day month, you can use the binomial probability mass function (PMF). The binomial PMF is defined as $binomial\_pmf(n, k, p) = {n \choose k} * p^k * (1-p)^{n-k}$. Calculate the probability of rain for 0, 1, or 2 days in a 30-day month, and the sum of these probabilities is approximately 0.411.

a_7.formal problem:
theorem
fixes probability :: real
assumes h0 : "probability = (binomial 30 0 * (1 / 10) ^ 0 * (1 - 1 / 10) ^ (30 - 0))
                 + (binomial 30 1 * (1 / 10) ^ 1 * (1 - 1 / 10) ^ (30 - 1))
                 + (binomial 30 2 * (1 / 10) ^ 2 * (1 - 1 / 10) ^ (30 - 2))"
shows  "0.411 \<le> probability \<and> probability \<le> 0.412"
a_7.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 The probability of getting rain on any given day in June in Capital City is $\frac{1}{10}$.  What is the probability that it rains on at most 2 days in June?  Express your answer as a decimal to the nearest thousandth. The final Answer is 0.411
 ### Proof
 There are 30 days in June. The probability that it rains on exactly 0, 1, or 2 days is  \begin{align}&\ \ \ \ \binom{30}{0}\bigg(\frac{1}{10}\bigg)^{\!0}\bigg(\frac{9}{10}\bigg)^{\!30}\\&+\binom{30}{1}\bigg(\frac{1}{10}\bigg)^{\!1}\bigg(\frac{9}{10}\bigg)^{\!29}\\&+\binom{30}{2}\bigg(\frac{1}{10}\bigg)^{\!2}\bigg(\frac{9}{10}\bigg)^{\!28} \\
 &\approx \boxed{0.411}.\end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes probability :: real
assumes h0 : "probability = (binomial 30 0 * (1 / 10) ^ 0 * (1 - 1 / 10) ^ (30 - 0))
                 + (binomial 30 1 * (1 / 10) ^ 1 * (1 - 1 / 10) ^ (30 - 1))
                 + (binomial 30 2 * (1 / 10) ^ 2 * (1 - 1 / 10) ^ (30 - 2))"
shows  "0.411 \<le> probability \<and> probability \<le> 0.412"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_7.informal problem: Calculate the probability that at most two successes will occur in 30 trials, given that the probability of success in a single trial is 1/10. The final answer should be between 0.411 and 0.412.

a_8.formal problem:
theorem
fixes p_rain :: real
assumes h0 : "p_rain = 1 / 10"
and h1 : "binomial_pmf 30 p_rain k = (choose 30 k) * (p_rain powr k) * ((1 - p_rain) powr (30 - k))"
shows  "sum (\<lambda>k. binomial_pmf 30 p_rain k) {0, 1, 2} = 0.411"
a_8.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 The probability of getting rain on any given day in June in Capital City is $\frac{1}{10}$.  What is the probability that it rains on at most 2 days in June?  Express your answer as a decimal to the nearest thousandth. The final Answer is 0.411
 ### Proof
 There are 30 days in June. The probability that it rains on exactly 0, 1, or 2 days is  \begin{align}&\ \ \ \ \binom{30}{0}\bigg(\frac{1}{10}\bigg)^{\!0}\bigg(\frac{9}{10}\bigg)^{\!30}\\&+\binom{30}{1}\bigg(\frac{1}{10}\bigg)^{\!1}\bigg(\frac{9}{10}\bigg)^{\!29}\\&+\binom{30}{2}\bigg(\frac{1}{10}\bigg)^{\!2}\bigg(\frac{9}{10}\bigg)^{\!28} \\
 &\approx \boxed{0.411}.\end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes p_rain :: real
assumes h0 : "p_rain = 1 / 10"
and h1 : "binomial_pmf 30 p_rain k = (choose 30 k) * (p_rain powr k) * ((1 - p_rain) powr (30 - k))"
shows  "sum (\<lambda>k. binomial_pmf 30 p_rain k) {0, 1, 2} = 0.411"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_8.informal problem: There is a 10% chance of rain each day. What is the probability that it rains on at most 2 of the next 30 days? The final answer is 0.411.

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes p_rain :: real
assumes h0 : "p_rain = 1 / 10"
and h1 : "binomial_distribution 30 p_rain"
shows  "CDF (binomial_distribution 30 p_rain) 2 = 0.411"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 The probability of getting rain on any given day in June in Capital City is $\frac{1}{10}$.  What is the probability that it rains on at most 2 days in June?  Express your answer as a decimal to the nearest thousandth. The final Answer is 0.411
 ### Proof
 There are 30 days in June. The probability that it rains on exactly 0, 1, or 2 days is  \begin{align}&\ \ \ \ \binom{30}{0}\bigg(\frac{1}{10}\bigg)^{\!0}\bigg(\frac{9}{10}\bigg)^{\!30}\\&+\binom{30}{1}\bigg(\frac{1}{10}\bigg)^{\!1}\bigg(\frac{9}{10}\bigg)^{\!29}\\&+\binom{30}{2}\bigg(\frac{1}{10}\bigg)^{\!2}\bigg(\frac{9}{10}\bigg)^{\!28} \\
 &\approx \boxed{0.411}.\end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes p_rain :: real
assumes h0 : "p_rain = 1 / 10"
and h1 : "binomial_distribution 30 p_rain"
shows  "CDF (binomial_distribution 30 p_rain) 2 = 0.411"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: Given that the probability of rain on any given day is 1/10, find the cumulative distribution function (CDF) for the binomial distribution with 30 trials (days) and a success threshold of 2 rainy days. The final answer is 0.411.
